data.name:
Web App Query Results 
(MySQL wire protocol)

labels:
Web App Query Results 
(MySQL wire protocol)

threats.title: Code Injection
threats.description: Attackers inject malicious code into input fields or URLs
threats.mitigation: Input validation / escaping; WAF; SAST/DAST

threats.title: Remote Code Execution (RCE)
threats.description: Exploiting vulnerabilities that let attackers run arbitrary code on your server.
threats.mitigation: Rapid patching; container isolation; SAST

threats.title: DDoS
threats.description: Botnets exhaust bandwidth/resources.
threats.mitigation: CDN/Anycast; auto‚Äëscaling; rate‚Äëlimiting

threats.title: DoS
threats.description: Single‚Äësource resource exhaustion (e.g., slow‚Äëloris).
threats.mitigation: Short timeouts; connection limits

threats.title: Broken Authentication
threats.description: Poor session management or credential flaws.
threats.mitigation: MFA; strong hashing (bcrypt); token rotation

threats.title: Directory Traversal
threats.description: Using ../ in URLs to access restricted files.
threats.mitigation: Path normalization; whitelists; chroot/jail

threats.title: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
threats.description: Exploiting a web server's ability to make HTTP requests on behalf of the attacker.
threats.mitigation: Destination allow‚Äëlist; block metadata IPs; WAF

threats.title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
threats.description: Injecting malicious scripts into web pages served to users.
threats.mitigation: Output encoding; CSP; input sanitization

threats.title: Misconfigured Security Headers
threats.description: Missing or misconfigured HTTP response headers.
threats.mitigation: Set headers like Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection.

threats.title: Information Leakage
threats.description: Server discloses sensitive info (e.g., stack traces, headers, debug messages).
threats.mitigation: Disable debug in prod; sanitize error output

threats.title: Open Redirects
threats.description: Web server accepts unvalidated redirects.
threats.mitigation: Allow‚Äëlist destinations; state tokens

threats.title: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
threats.description: Trick users into submitting unwanted requests to your server while they‚Äôre logged in.
threats.mitigation: CSRF tokens; SameSite cookies; origin check

threats.title: Broken Access Control / IDOR
threats.description: Endpoints allow unauthorized access or modification of resources (Insecure Direct Object Reference).
threats.mitigation: Enforce server‚Äëside authorization checks; least‚Äëprivilege APIs; rigorous test cases

threats.title: Insecure Deserialization
threats.description: Untrusted data is deserialized leading to RCE, data tampering or DOS.
threats.mitigation: Avoid native serialization of untrusted data; integrity signatures; deserialization firewalls

threats.title: XML External Entity (XXE)
threats.description: XML parsers process external entities allowing file read, SSRF or DOS.
threats.mitigation: Disable DTDs/external entities; switch to safe parsers; WAF regex filters

threats.title: Server‚ÄëSide Template Injection (SSTI)
threats.description: User input injected into template engine expressions leading to code execution.
threats.mitigation: Strict template delimiters; sandbox templates; input validation

threats.title: Mass Assignment
threats.description: Automatic binding of HTTP parameters to object fields lets attacker overwrite sensitive properties.
threats.mitigation: Allow list bindable fields; DTOs; security-focused frameworks

threats.title: Business Logic Abuse
threats.description: Legitimate features mis‚Äëused in unexpected order/volume to subvert business rules.
threats.mitigation: Threat modeling; usage rate‚Äëlimits; server‚Äëside invariant checks

threats.title: Insecure Randomness
threats.description: Predictable tokens, IDs or OTPs allow guessing and takeover.
threats.mitigation: Use cryptographically secure PRNGs; sufficient entropy; periodic rotation

threats.title: HTTP Request Smuggling (Back‚Äëend)
threats.description: Front/back proxy parsing mismatch enabling cache poisoning or credential bypass.
threats.mitigation: Consistent parser versions; disable conflicting encodings; detailed logging

threats.title: Web Shell Uploads
threats.description: Attackers upload malicious files (like PHP, JSP, or Python scripts) that give remote shell access via the browser.
threats.mitigation:
- Strict file validation (type, size, extension).
- Block script execution in upload directories via .htaccess, Nginx rules, etc"

threats.title: Directory Traversal
threats.description: Attackers manipulate paths like ../../etc/passwd to access sensitive files.
threats.mitigation:
"- Normalize paths, whitelist directories, never rely on user input for file paths.
- Disable directory listings in web server config."

threats.title: Unauthorized File Downloads
threats.description: Improper access controls allow direct file downloads (e.g., logs, configs, private PDFs).
threats.mitigation:
- Enforce access controls on all files.
- Move sensitive files outside the web root."

threats.title: Insecure Permissions
threats.description: Files or folders have overly permissive access (chmod 777, or owner is www-data for everything).
threats.mitigation:
- Use chown, chmod, and group ownership properly.
- Enforce least privilege for web server users"

threats.title: Symbolic Link Abuse
threats.description: Malicious symlinks point from a web-accessible folder to sensitive areas (like /etc/ or /home/).
threats.mitigation:
- Scan for unexpected symlinks.
- Use chroot or container isolation."

threats.title: Exposed Backup Files
threats.description: Developers leave .bak, .zip, .tar, .sql, or .old files in the web root.
threats.mitigation:
- Never store backup or development artifacts in web-accessible folders.
- Automate cleanup with scripts or CI/CD checks."

threats.title: Tampered Static Assets
threats.description: JavaScript, CSS, or images modified to inject malware or tracking (supply chain attacks).
threats.mitigation:
- Use Subresource Integrity (SRI).
- Monitor file hashes for changes (integrity scanning)."

threats.title: Log Injection / Poisoning
threats.description: Attacker injects malicious data into logs (e.g., via headers, user agents).
threats.mitigation:
- Sanitize all user-controlled log inputs.
- Store logs in write-only or append-only formats."

threats.title: Insecure File Inclusion (LFI/RFI)
threats.description: Web apps dynamically include files using user input (e.g., include($_GET['page'])).
threats.mitigation: Sanitize/validate all paths before inclusion.

threats.title: Sensitive Config Files in Web Root
threats.description: Files like .env, config.php, wp-config.php, or .htaccess are exposed.
threats.mitigation:
- Move configs outside web root.
- Deny access via web server rules (e.g., location ~ /\.(env|htaccess)$ in Nginx)."

threats.title: Ransomware Encryption
threats.description: Malware encrypts application data and demands ransom.
threats.mitigation: Offline backups; SELinux/AppArmor; real‚Äëtime AV; incident playbooks

threats.title: World‚ÄëReadable Temp Files
threats.description: Temporary files created with insecure permissions leak sensitive data.
threats.mitigation: umask hardening; secure tmp dirs; periodic scans

threats.title: Hard Link Abuse
threats.description: Attackers create hard links to sensitive files to bypass ACL changes.
threats.mitigation: fs.protected_hardlinks; disallow links in upload dirs; integrity scans

threats.title: Residual Data in Deleted Files
threats.description: Deleted files remain recoverable on disk snapshots or backups.
threats.mitigation: Secure wipe; encrypted filesystems; snapshot lifecycle management

threats.title: Credential Leakage via OS Crash Dumps
threats.description: Core dumps containing secrets stored in accessible locations.
threats.mitigation: Disable core dumps or restrict path; scrub sensitive data; limit ulimit -c

threats.title: Insecure File Metadata Exposure
threats.description: File metadata (EXIF, document properties) leaks sensitive info to users.
threats.mitigation: Strip metadata on upload; content scanning; user education

threats.title: Mounting External Volumes Insecurely
threats.description: External drives or mounted folders are readable/writable by the web server without proper security.
threats.mitigation:
- Mount with noexec, nosuid, nodev where applicable.
- Use access control lists (ACLs) to restrict users."

threats.title: SQL Injection (SQLi)
threats.description: Unsanitized input is used to inject malicious SQL queries.
threats.mitigation: Prepared statements; ORM; WAF

threats.title: File Upload Vulnerabilities
threats.description: Web apps allow file uploads but fail to properly validate the files.
threats.mitigation: Strict MIME/extension checks; disable execution

threats.title: Weak or Default Credentials
threats.description: Using usernames like root with weak passwords (or none at all).
threats.mitigation: Enforce strong passwords, disable remote root login, and use least privilege.

threats.title: Exposed MySQL Port (3306)
threats.description: MySQL server is publicly accessible.
threats.mitigation:
"- Bind MySQL to localhost (or use a private network).
- Use a firewall to restrict access to trusted IPs."

threats.title: Privilege Escalation
threats.description: Overprivileged accounts can modify or execute harmful queries.
threats.mitigation: Apply principle of least privilege for all accounts.

threats.title: Data Exfiltration via SELECT / INTO OUTFILE
threats.description: If attackers gain access, they can dump data to a file and retrieve it.
threats.mitigation: Disable INTO OUTFILE and restrict write permissions to MySQL user.

threats.title: Unencrypted Connections (No TLS)
threats.description: Data, including credentials, flows in cleartext over the network.
threats.mitigation: Enable SSL/TLS for MySQL connections.

threats.title: Local File Inclusion via LOAD DATA INFILE
threats.description: If not disabled, attackers can use this command to read sensitive files.
threats.mitigation: Disable LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE unless absolutely required.

threats.title: Unpatched Vulnerabilities
threats.description: Running outdated versions of MySQL can expose you to known exploits.
threats.mitigation: Regularly patch and monitor security advisories.

threats.title: Information Disclosure via Errors
threats.description: MySQL error messages reveal schema names, structure, or even partial queries.
threats.mitigation: Sanitize errors before sending them to clients; disable verbose errors in production.

threats.title: Backup Theft or Exposure
threats.description: Backups stored insecurely (e.g., in /tmp, public S3 buckets).
threats.mitigation: Encrypt and store backups securely, and restrict access.

threats.title: Denial of Service via Heavy Queries
threats.description: Resource-intensive queries lock tables or spike CPU/IO.
threats.mitigation: Rate-limit users, enforce query timeouts, and monitor for unusual activity.

threats.title: Brute Force Attack on User Accounts
threats.description: Attackers try lots of passwords on known users (root, admin, etc.).
threats.mitigation: Use fail2ban or other login attempt monitoring tools.

threats.title: Unsafe Stored Procedures / Functions
threats.description: Procedures created with SQL SECURITY DEFINER run with elevated privileges and can be abused.
threats.mitigation: Review DEFINER privileges; limit CREATE ROUTINE; code review

threats.title: Binary Log Poisoning
threats.description: Malicious statements inserted into replication binlogs compromise replicas.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt/validate binlogs; restricted REPLICATE privilege; checksum enforcement

threats.title: Federated Table Abuse
threats.description: FEDERATED engine queries remote servers, allowing SSRF or data leak if misconfigured.
threats.mitigation: Disable FEDERATED unless needed; validate hostnames; network ACLs

threats.title: Malicious Triggers for Persistence
threats.description: Triggers added to run malicious code or leak data whenever rows change.
threats.mitigation: Audit triggers; least‚Äëprivilege on TRIGGER; metadata integrity checks

threats.title: Unencrypted Data at Rest
threats.description: Data files and backups stored unencrypted, exposing data if disk stolen.
threats.mitigation: TDE (InnoDB encryption); disk/LUKS encryption; secure backup keys

threats.title: General Query Log Exposure
threats.description: General query log left enabled and world‚Äëreadable, leaking credentials and queries.
threats.mitigation: Disable in production; secure file permissions; rotate logs

threats.title: Eavesdropping
threats.description: Attacker captures clear-text traffic between client and server.
threats.mitigation: Enforce HTTPS (HSTS) ‚Ä¢ TLS 1.2+ ‚Ä¢ Disable plain HTTP

threats.title: Replay Attack
threats.description: Re-sending captured legitimate requests (e.g., payments).
threats.mitigation: Nonces/time-stamps Unique session tokens TLS

threats.title: SSL/TLS stripping or downgrade attack
threats.description: The attacker downgrades an HTTPS connection to HTTP, allowing them to read the unencrypted data being exchanged.
threats.mitigation: Redirect HTTP access attempts to HTTPS, among others

threats.title: Weak Encryption Standard
threats.description: Using weak or deprecated encryption standards such as SSL
threats.mitigation: Disable weak suites; TLS‚ÄØ1.2/1.3‚Äëonly; modern ciphers

threats.title: Transparent Proxy Interception
threats.description: he attacker sits between the user and server (e.g., via a rogue router or compromised ISP), acting as a silent proxy.
threats.mitigation: Certificate pinning; DNSSEC / DoH; TLS

threats.title: Session Hijacking (Cookie Theft / Sidejacking)
threats.description: Compromising session cookies via network sniffing or injection to impersonate a user.
threats.mitigation: Secure & HttpOnly cookies; SameSite; TLS; re‚Äëauthentication; token rotation

threats.title: DNS Spoofing / Cache Poisoning
threats.description: Attacker poisons DNS responses to redirect user traffic to a malicious host.
threats.mitigation: DNSSEC; DoH/DoT; short TTLs; monitor for DNS anomalies

threats.title: HTTP Request Smuggling
threats.description: Abusing inconsistencies between front‚Äëend and back‚Äëend HTTP parsing to smuggle requests.
threats.mitigation: Align proxy/server parsing; disable legacy transfer encodings; WAF rules

threats.title: TLS Interception (with Forged Certificates)
threats.description: Attacker presents a forged TLS certificate to the client while communicating with the server using the real certificate.
threats.mitigation: Certificate pinning; trusted public CAs; OCSP stapling

threats.title: Log Injection / Forgery
threats.description: Attacker crafts inputs (headers, user-agents, etc.) to write fake or malicious entries that mislead analysts.
threats.mitigation:
Sanitize all log fields 
Use structured logging (JSON) 
Escape control characters

threats.title: Log Tampering After Write
threats.description: Insider or attacker with access modifies or deletes existing log files to cover tracks.
threats.mitigation:
Write-once / append-only storage (WORM, immutability) 
Cryptographic signing / hash-chaining 
RBAC on logs

threats.title: Unencrypted Log Transport
threats.description: Logs shipped over the network (Syslog, Fluentd, Beats) without TLS can be sniffed or altered.
threats.mitigation:
TLS/Mutual-TLS for log shippers 
VPN or private network links

threats.title: Sensitive Data in Logs (PII / Secrets)
threats.description: Application logs inadvertently capture credentials, tokens, or personal data.
threats.mitigation:
Log scrubbing / redaction middleware 
Classification & DLP scans 
Developer guidelines

threats.title: Excessive Log Retention
threats.description: Logs kept indefinitely increase breach impact and cost.
threats.mitigation:
Retention policy (e.g., 90 days) 
Lifecycle rules / automatic deletion

threats.title: Insufficient Log Retention
threats.description: Logs rolled-over too quickly, hampering investigations / compliance.
threats.mitigation:
Align retention with regulatory & forensic needs 
Capacity planning

threats.title: Log Overflow / Disk Exhaustion
threats.description: Massive log volume fills disk, crashing services (DoS).
threats.mitigation:
Log rotation & compression 
Dedicated partition 
Alert on utilisation

threats.title: Unsecured Central Log Repository
threats.description: Central log directory or network share is world-readable or lacks encryption/ACLs, exposing all logs to any user on the network.
threats.mitigation:
Tight filesystem / share permissions (read-only for SIEM, no public ‚Äúothers‚Äù access) 
Encrypt logs at rest 
Network segmentation / VPN for log collectors 
Regular audits of share permissions

threats.title: Missing Integrity Monitoring
threats.description: No mechanism to verify logs weren‚Äôt altered in transit or at rest.
threats.mitigation:
HMAC / digital signatures 
Chain-of-custody audit trails 
SIEM alerts on hash mismatch

threats.title: Lack of Real-Time Alerting
threats.description: Critical events are logged but no alert is raised, delaying response.
threats.mitigation:
Define alert rules / thresholds 
Regular rule testing
